I.  INTRODUCTION 
1.  The Government of India regards the generation of productive and gainful employment 
to  absorb  India’s  growing  labor  force  as  being  critical  for  facilitating  inclusive  growth  and 
enhancing the overall productivity of the economy. Therefore, during the country programming 
mission held in May 2011, the government indicated that the Asian Development Bank (ADB) 
should  support  the  National  Skill  Development  Corporation  (NSDC)  in  operationalizing  the 
mandate  of  India’s  National  Skills  Policy,  2009.  Accordingly,  this  $1.1  million  capacity 
development technical assistance (TA) for ―Financing Skills Development‖ was included in the 
2011 nonlending program for India.1 Based on subsequent discussions with NSDC, the project 
name was changed to ―Skill Development for Inclusive Growth.‖ The design and monitoring 
framework (DMF) for the TA is in Appendix 1.2 
 
II.  ISSUES 
2.  India’s National Skills Policy, 2009, aims to provide skills to 500 million people by 2022 
by creating skills systems that have a high degree of inclusiveness in terms of gender, rural 
versus urban, organized versus unorganized, and traditional versus contemporary jobs. The 
policy emphasizes that skills development initiatives should be dynamic, demand-based, and 
closely aligned with government policies on economic growth, employment generation, and 
social development. A three-tier institutional structure-consisting of (i) the National Council on 
Skill  Development  chaired  by  the  Prime  Minister,  (ii)  the  National  Skill  Development 
Coordination Board chaired by the deputy chairman of the Planning Commission, and (iii) the 
NSDC-has been set up to fulfill this challenging mandate.  
 
3.  The capacity of the existing skills development programs has to be raised from 3.1 
million per annum to around 15 million per annum to train the new entrants to the labor market. 
India’s skill development initiatives need to address three types of imbalances that have arisen 
due to the rapid structural changes in its economy over the past decade and a half: (i) a 
geographic imbalance since the states with the highest population and labor force growth are 
also the ones lagging in terms of growth and job creation; (ii) a demand−supply imbalance since 
the work force being created in terms of quality and profile is not aligned with the evolving 
demand; and (iii) a sectoral mismatch since the current education system is not providing the 
skills  required  by  the  fast-growing  sectors.3 Both  the  quality  and  capacity  of  India’s  skills 
development programs need significant strengthening. 
 
4.  NSDC has been set up as a public−private partnership (PPP) under Section 25 of the 
Companies  Act,  1956,  for  catalyzing  skills  development  through  private  entities,  and  to 
supplement and revitalize government-led vocational training and skills development programs 
that have been the norm until now. Its mandate is to provide skills to 150 million people by 2022. 
NSDC has a core equity base of $2.2 million of which the Government of India accounts for 
49%  and  the  private  sector  for  the  remaining  51%.  A  tiered  decision-making  structure 
comprising a board, board sub-committees and an executive council helps NSDC to operate in 
a transparent and effective manner. It draws on the National Skill Development Fund, a 100% 
government-owned trust fund run by professional fund managers, to support the following broad 
types of activities. First, NSDC encourages private sector investment in profit and nonprofit 
enterprises  in  training  and  skill  development  in  20  high-growth  sectors  and  the  huge

2   
unorganized sector to build capacity in the technical and vocational education and training 
(TVET)  segment.4 NSDC  provides  viability  gap funding through  loans, equity,  or grants.  It 
employs  a  phased  and  detailed  due-diligence  process  based  on  the  following  criteria:  (i) 
employer view of demand for the specific skills to be provided; (ii) skills gap analysis of the 21 
sectors covered by NSDC including the unorganized sector; (iii) alignment with NSDC's mission; 
(iv) robustness of the overall plan and operating model; and (iv) ability to leverage partnerships 
and  financial  resources.  Entities  eligible  for  funding  include  industry,  training  and  skill 
development organizations, nongovernment organizations, business associations, and social 
entrepreneurs. NSDC does not finance land acquisition or the construction of buildings because 
it want to encourage more efficient use of the existing infrastructure, and instead focus on 
improving training and skills development programs. As of 18 August 2011, NSDC had signed 
39 memorandums of understanding amounting to $225 million for providing skills to 37.74 
million people by 2022.  
 
5.  Second,  NSDC  is  mandated  by  the  National  Skills  Policy  to  develop  an  enabling 
environment for skills development. It has to lay down sector-specific competencies, quality 
assurance and certification standards by facilitating the creation of sector skills councils (SSCs) 
as national partnership organizations involving all relevant stakeholders from industry, labor, 
and academia in the particular sector. The core functions of the SSCs can be grouped under the 
following categories:  
 
(i)  Research. The SSCs have to identify the current and projected skills gaps in their 
sectors and catalogue the types, range, and depth of skills required. They have to 
develop sector-specific skills and competency standards, and benchmark these with 
international occupation standards. SSCs would also prepare skills development plans, 
maintain  a  skills  inventory  database,  and  establish  sector-specific  labor  market 
information systems to assist in the planning and delivery of training.  
 
(ii)  Quality assurance. The SSCs are responsible for standardizing and streamlining the 
affiliation and accreditation process—i.e., certification tests for employees and trainers to 
ensure consistency and acceptability of standards. They also have to participate in the 
accreditation and certification of courses specific to or related to their sectors.  
 
(iii) Delivery. The SSCs will develop and update course modules, and train good quality 
trainers. They would have to partner with educational institutions to train trainers and 
upgrade skill sets of existing industry employees and those in the industry’s value chain 
including dealer and service networks. SSCs are also mandated to promote academies 
of excellence. 
 
6.  NSDC  has  already  approved  eight  SSCs  for  the  following  sectors:  (i)  automobile 
manufacturing; (ii) private security; (iii) energy; (iv) media, animation, gaming, and films; (v) 
information technology and information technology-enabled services; (vi) health care; (vii) retail; 
and (viii) banking and financial services. Proposals for setting up SSCs in other sectors such as 
transport and logistics, food processing, electronics, handicrafts, and gems and jewelry are 
expected to be approved by February 2012.  
 
                                                
4  Sectors include automobile and auto components, textiles and garments, leather and leather goods, gems and 
jewelry, building and construction, food processing, tourism hospitality and travel trade, transport and logistics, 
warehousing,  packaging,  organized  retail,  health  care,  banking,  insurance,  finance,  education,  and  skills 
development services.

3 
7.  Effective operationalization of SSCs and the establishment of suitable linkages with the 
proposed national vocational qualifications framework (NVQF), currently being designed by the 
Ministry of Labor and Employment (MOLE), is critical to ensure that all the skills development 
programs being supported by NSDC and the various ministries (including MOLE, Ministry of 
Rural Development, Ministry of Power, and Ministry of Road Transport and Highways) can be 
carried on in a harmonized and structured manner. Given the complexity of the tasks that have 
to be carried out by the SSCs, and the fact that they need to bring together and ensure 
sustained  coordination  across  all  relevant  stakeholders  at  the  national  and  state  levels, 
significant technical assistance will be required. Since SSCs will lay the foundation on which 
India’s skills development initiatives will be built, the importance of rolling them out effectively 
cannot be overemphasized.  
 
8.  ADB’s current country partnership strategy (2009−2012) focuses on supporting India’s 
efforts towards facilitating inclusive and sustainable growth.5  The country operations business 
plan  for  2012−2014  also  highlights  the  importance  of  human  development  including  skills 
development with a focus on the infrastructure sectors, productive employment generation, and 
enhanced health and social protection outcomes (footnote 1). The TA is therefore fully aligned 
with ADB’s India program and Strategy 2020, 6 and will prepare the groundwork for future ADB 
operations in the priority area of skill development in India.  
 
III.  THE TECHNICAL ASSISTANCE 
9.  The TA will assist NSDC in establishing one SSC each in the service sector (such as 
health care) and infrastructure sector (such as transport and logistics or construction). These 
are  priority  areas  with  significant  employment  and  development  potential.  By  2022,  the 
incremental demand for trained and certified workers in the allied health care segment (e.g., 
operation theatre and laboratory technicians, community health workers) is estimated at 12.7 
million, while that in the transport and logistics sector is projected at 17.7 million. By building the 
capacity of two pilot SSCs, the TA will provide a template for other SSCs, thereby helping 
NSDC in fulfilling a key part of their mandate. The following activities will be carried out under 
the TA to help make the SSCs operational: (i) identifying focus areas for skills development 
based on market analysis and stakeholder consultations by the SSCs; (ii) scoping the functions 
of the SSC; (iii) firming up the constitution (membership) and governance system of the SSC; 
(iv) preparing a financial sustainability model and budget estimates for the functioning of the 
SSC;  and  (v)  preparing  support  documentation  and  toolkits  to  assist  in  the  subsequent 
functioning of the SSC. 
 
10.  The TA will also support two states (as pilots) in linking their skills development missions 
more effectively with the new, PPP-driven skill development initiatives being promoted by NSDC 
and other government-run schemes at the national level.7  
 
A.  Impact and Outcome 
11.  The impact of the TA will be that NSDC’s approach to skills development becomes 
sustainable.  The  outcome  of  the  TA  will  be  that  NSDC’s  skills  development  institutional 
framework and operational guidelines are developed for replication across more sectors. By

assisting NSDC in making two SSCs operational, the TA will pave the way for the rollout of 
other SSCs in the services and infrastructure sectors. ADB will also help to effectively link the 
skills development missions of two (pilot) states with the skills development initiatives of NSDC 
and the central ministries. The scoping studies and road maps prepared will be useful in guiding 
NSDC in supporting skills development initiatives across states including under the proposed 
ADB loan.  
 
B.  Methodology and Key Activities 
12.  The TA will work towards achieving this outcome by supporting the following broad 
outputs: (i) NSDC assisted in establishing two SSCs; (ii) improved linkage between the skills 
development missions of two (pilot) states with national skills development initiatives; (iii) policy 
makers  informed  about  best  practices  in  skills  development;  and  (iv)  project  activities 
undertaken in a timely manner and within budget. The formulation of the SSCs will include 
governance frameworks laying down social and gender-sensitive occupation standards, quality 
assurance and accreditation procedures, and standards for both trainees and trainers. The TA 
will delineate appropriate representation of all relevant stakeholders in the SSCs, draft template 
memorandums of understanding to specify their roles and responsibilities, and finalize a road 
map with milestones for the rollout. The TA will also focus on creating a sustainable financial 
structure, staffing requirements, and initial budgets for the functioning of the SSCs. Manuals will 
be prepared to guide sector functional analysis, train trainers, and prepare quality assurance 
standards and competency frameworks, LMIS reports, and monitoring and evaluation reports.   
 
13.  Most states have also set up skills development missions and are increasingly looking 
towards NSDC for guidance to improve the design and delivery of their own skills programs. 
The TA will therefore help to prepare scoping studies on the skills development missions of two 
states (as pilots), elaborating how they can link up effectively with the new, private-sector-driven 
skills development initiatives being promoted by NSDC and various government schemes at the 
national level. Career guidance and social marketing campaigns will also be undertaken to raise 
awareness about the importance of technical and vocational training, the need to enhance one’s 
skills, and the various initiatives of the government and NSDC.  
 
14.  Knowledge  products  focusing  on  international  best  practice  in  the  area  of  skills 
development and sector skills councils will be prepared to enrich the policy dialogue. The 
findings of these knowledge products will be disseminated through workshops and focus-group 
discussions involving key stakeholders including NSDC, the Planning Commission, relevant 
ministries, private sector representatives, chambers of commerce, NGOs, and donor partners. 
This will help to ensure that all stakeholders coordinate well and respond appropriately to the 
new skills development initiatives being supported by NSDC. Suitable financing options which 
can sustain skills development for poorer students, especially those living in small cities and 
rural areas, will also be examined.  
    
C.  Cost and Financing 
15.  The Government of India has requested ADB to finance $1.1 million equivalent, which 
will be financed on a grant basis by ADB’s Technical Assistance Special Fund (TASF-other 
sources).  The  government  and  counterpart  contributions  will  be  in-kind  and  cover  office 
accommodation, transportation, and counterpart staff salaries, as required. Cost estimates and 
the financing plan are in Appendix 2.

5 
D.  Implementation Arrangements 
16.  The Department of Economic Affairs under the Ministry of Finance will be the executing 
agency for this TA. NSDC will be the implementing agency. A TA steering committee comprising 
representatives from the Department of Economic Affairs, NSDC, and other relevant entities will 
be  constituted.  It  will  meet  periodically  and  provide  overall  policy  direction,  and  facilitate 
coordination among concerned government and private agencies.  
 
17.  A total of 61 person-months of consulting inputs will be provided under the TA: 18 
person-months of international and 43 person-months of national consultants. ADB will engage 
the consultants through a firm (54 person-months), using a simplified proposal for the quality- 
and  cost-based  selection  method,  as  well  as  on  an  individual  basis  (7  person-months)  in 
accordance with ADB’s Guidelines on the Use of Consultants (2010, as amended from time to 
time). All TA-financed goods will be procured in line with ADB's Procurement Guidelines (2010, 
as amended from time to time). All disbursements under the TA will be done in accordance with 
ADB's Technical Assistance Disbursement Handbook (2010, as amended from time to time). 
Equipment such as laptops, printers, photocopiers, and other required items procured under the 
TA will be handed over to NSDC upon completion of the project. The advance payment facility 
may be used for payment of eligible costs. The TA will be implemented over 24 months with 
expected commencement in January 2012 and completion in January 2014.  
 
IV.  THE PRESIDENT'S DECISION 
18.  The President, acting under the authority delegated by the Board, has approved the 
provision of technical assistance not exceeding the equivalent of $1,100,000 on a grant basis to 
the Government of India for Skills Development for Inclusive Growth, and hereby reports this 
action to the Board.

OUTLINE TERMS OF REFERENCE FOR CONSULTANTS 
 
A.  Consulting Firm   
 
1.  Capacity development and technical and vocational education and training policy 
specialist and team leader (1 international consultant, 10 person-months). An international 
specialist is proposed for this role given the interrelatedness of all the capacity building and 
policy development activities. He or she will be helped by two national consultants to undertake 
the following: 
 
(i)  Assist the National Skill Development Corporation (NSDC) to design two pilot sector 
skills councils (SSCs). The specialist will draft the required policies and develop the 
institutional structure of the SSCs to deliver, assess, and certify the industry occupation 
standards. He or she will review the current structure of the skills development missions 
of the two states and suggest ways of linking them up with the skills development 
initiatives of NSDC, particularly in the two pilot sectors on which this technical assistance 
focuses. The specialist will strengthen NSDC’s policies and processes to support SSCs, 
accredit institutions to deliver training programs, and monitor their overall effectiveness. 
 
(ii)  To ensure sustainability, the specialist will train a small cadre of trainers who would be 
able to undertake capacity building and institutional strengthening activities for other 
SSCs over time. Suitable institutions will be identified to provide capacity building and 
training to other SSCs and the contracted teaching institutions. Preferably, this will be 
done at the initial stage of the TA so that the identified institutions are able to provide 
some experts who can work intermittently in teams and continue to support the formation 
of other SSCs. Specifically, the specialist will also do the following: 
 
(a) Review NSDC’s policies and procedures for the accreditation of institutions to deliver 
training programs based on the identified industry competencies. The specialist will 
work with relevant stakeholders and other donor partners to align the emerging 
Indian national vocational qualification framework (NVQF) with NSDC/SSC-driven 
occupational standards.  
(b) Support  NSDC  in  developing  policies  and  procedures  so  that  nationally  and 
internationally  recognized  NVQF  certificates  can  be  awarded  to  students  and 
trainees. This will also require setting up of systems to monitor student assessment 
and promote consistency of assessment outcomes.  
(c)  Help to strengthen the skills development mission in two pilot states so that they can 
better  support  and monitor the  accredited  training. The  specialist  will  work  with 
managers and teaching staff of the selected training institutions and ensure that they 
effectively  deliver  the  NSDC/SSC  accredited  programs  of  competency-based 
training.   
(d) Train a core team of TVET staff to develop training programs based on the identified 
industry competencies. The specialist will train a core team of TVET teachers to 
assess students and trainees against the identified competencies.  
(e) Draft standardized policy and operations manuals that can be used as guides by all 
SSCs. Make recommendations on funding of the SSCs to promote their long-term 
fiscal sustainability.  
(f)  Identify policy implications and work with other government agencies to promote a 
unified national approach to TVET in India, and train a small cadre of trainers (who 
may be from the identified institutions).

(g) Analyze  the  working  of  SSCs  and  suggest  suitable  options  for  creating  an 
association  of  SSCs  which  would  provide  a  forum  for  discussion  on  areas  of 
common  interest.  The  association  will  help  to  review  and  refine  policies  and 
guidelines related to the common activities of the SSCs such as national occupation 
standards, accreditation of training institutions, assessment and certification, and 
establishment of labor market information system (LMIS).  
(h) Set up systems for creating SSC associations based on consultations with NSDC, 
SSCs, and other relevant stakeholders.  
(i)  Based on the experience gained during implementation of this TA, the Team leader 
will also work with ADB staff in designing the proposed loan.  
2.  Capacity development and technical and vocational education and training policy 
specialists (2 national consultants, 4 person-months each). The consultancy firm will also 
provide  two  national  capacity  development  and  TVET  policy  specialists  to  support  the 
international consultant in undertaking the tasks specified in paragraph 1 above.  
 
3.  Sector functional analysis facilitator (1 international consultant, 5 person-months). 
To ensure that the initiatives supported through the TA are sustainable, the facilitator will train a 
small  national  team  in  undertaking  functional  analysis—i.e.,  the  systematic  process  of  
identifying and defining the key functions of a worker—and  drafting the national occupation 
standards for the two pilot SSCs. He or she will also prepare the required manuals for both, the 
functional analysis process and the writing of competency (occupation) standards. Specifically, 
the consultant will do the following: 
 
(i)  Demonstrate and manage the full functional analysis process in the two selected sectors 
leading to the final confirmation of nationally agreed standards and the packaging of at 
least two complete vocational qualifications at different levels. 
(ii)  Train the national team to continue the facilitation with other sectors involving them in all 
aspects of the development of industry standards in the demonstration sectors.  
(iii) Propose a suitable format for specifying occupation standards based on current best 
practice in the writing of standards and train the team in this.  
(iv) Prepare functional analysis and standards writing operations manuals for the SSCs and 
NSDC. 
4.  The facilitator will work with the two pilot SSCs to bring together industry practitioners to 
conduct a sector level identification of workforce occupational standards. These standards will 
include assessment of technical and employability skills, and will be assembled into vocational 
qualifications  packages  from  prevocational  to  advanced  technician  levels  to  meet  the 
requirements of the national and international labor markets. 
 
5.  Sector functional analysis facilitators (2 national consultants, 4 person-months 
each). The consultancy firm will also provide two national sector functional analysis facilitators 
to support the international consultant in undertaking the tasks specified in paragraphs 3 and 4.  
 
6.  Career guidance and social marketing specialist (1 national consultant, 4 person-
months). A career guidance and social marketing campaign is required to create awareness 
about the importance of vocational and technical training for enhancing one’s earning potential 
and  career  prospects.  The  campaign  should  have  a  strong  gender  focus,  and  encourage 
women to enhance their skills by enrolling in suitable technical and vocational programs. It 
should also be targeted towards enhancing the awareness of the relatively poor segments in 
both, rural and urban areas about how technical and vocational training can help them to 
enhance their income-earning potential. The campaign will help to counter the commonly held

perception that careers in vocational and technical fields have low status and limited earning 
potential. The career guidance and social marketing specialist will help to supplement NSDC’s 
ongoing initiatives in this area in the following ways: 
 
(i)  Develop a strategy to increase public awareness about the importance of enhancing 
one’s skills through technical and vocational training especially in the context of India’s 
economic growth. The strategy will help to disseminate information on the various skill 
development initiatives and emphasize the importance of getting formal certification.  
(ii)  Develop a plan for improving career awareness and vocational counselling.  
(iii) Design a social marketing plan and prepare social marketing material. 
(iv) Train trainers and SSC staff in career guidance and counselling, and assist them in 
establishing career guidance and placement services for their sectors.   
 
7.  Labor market information and advice specialists (2 national consultants, 2 person-
months each). High quality and up-to-date labor market information and advice is required at 
the  national,  state,  and  sector  levels  to  guide  NSDC,  the  SSCs,  training  institutions,  the 
government, and most importantly, the workforce. Each SSC has to establish a labor market 
information system (LMIS) so that it can have an accurate and dynamic assessment of the 
employment trend and skills requirement (by region and state) of the particular sector and its 
subsectors. The labor market information and advice specialists will help the two SSCs in 
analyzing the data being collected by the LMIS, and structure it in a manner which allows easy 
inference of changing demand−supply trends. The specialists’ tasks will include the following: 
 
(i)  Train NSDC and SSC staff in collecting and analyzing labor market data to identify 
employment  trends.  The  specialists  will  also  establish  mechanisms  that  allow  the 
identified trends to be reflected in the planning and delivery of training programs, setting 
up of training centers, training of trainers, and interaction with all stakeholders especially 
the workforce.  
(ii)  Ensure  that  the  LMIS  collects  and  analyzes  data  pertaining  to  skills  development 
opportunities for women and traditionally disadvantaged groups so that the programs of 
NSDC and the ministries can be tailored accordingly. 
(iii) Work with the skills development missions of the two selected states so that they can 
also be trained in analyzing labor market information, and drawing policy inferences from 
it. 
(iv) Prepare  a  manual  for  guiding  the  design  and  use  of  LMIS  to  ensure  continued 
relevance, and develop reporting mechanisms so that the NSDC can be assured that the 
SSCs are tracking and using the LMIS information as required.  
(v)  The consultants will also coordinate with the key people involved in the LMIS initiative at 
the Ministry of Labor and Employment to ensure that the LMISs being developed by the 
two SSCs link up well with the national LMIS.   
8.  Monitoring and evaluation specialist (1 national consultant, 3 person-months). The 
specialist will work closely with staff of NSDC and the two pilot SSCs to provide training on 
benefit monitoring and evaluation. The techniques will include design of survey instruments, 
data collection, processing, and analysis to ensure quality of the training providers who are 
accredited by the SSCs. The specialist will complement the ongoing monitoring and evaluation 
initiatives of NSDC and help to:  
 
(i)  Determine the key indicators which can help in tracking the performance of SSCs.  
(ii)  Identify ways of capturing data supporting the key indicators.

(iii) Establish procedures for the routine monitoring of the effectiveness of contracted training 
and of the work of the training providers.  
(iv) Coach staff in the proper collection and processing of primary data. The specialist will 
prepare periodic monitoring and evaluation reports and a monitoring and evaluation 
manual to ensure standardization and sustainability. 
 
9.  Labor economist and skills development specialists (2 national consultants, 3 
person-months each). These national consultants will work with the capacity development and 
TVET policy specialists and focus on one of the two selected states each. Their tasks will 
include the following: 
 
(i)  Review the existing programs for skills development and vocational training within the 
state,  and  assess  how  relevant  and  effective  these  programs  are.  Based  on  the 
economic growth strategy of the state, and its natural and human resource endowment, 
each specialist will prepare a roadmap for the state on how best to link up with various 
national programs and initiatives on skills development and vocational training programs 
being run by the 17 ministries and NSDC in line with the opportunities and needs of the 
particular state.   
(ii)  Coordinate with the capacity development and TVET policy specialists to ensure that 
appropriate courses are designed and delivered by the training institutes.  
10.  Public−private partnership and finance expert (1 national consultant, 3 person-
months).  NSDC  is  supporting  private-sector-led  efforts,  including  nonprofit  and  for-profit 
initiatives  with  the  goal  of  building  models  that  are  scalable.  A  differentiated  approach  is 
required depending on the marketability of the skills group and the income level of the target 
student population.  To help NSDC develop low-cost, yet high quality innovative business and 
financing models especially for the poor candidates, an expert in PPP and finance will be fielded 
to: 
 
(i)  Gather feedback from the private training providers who have received funding from 
NSDC for undertaking different types of skills development programs, assess how well 
these programs are functioning, and report on whether they will be financially viable in 
the long run or not.  
(ii)  Suggest innovative financing options and models to ensure sustainability, especially for 
programs which are trying to target poorer and vulnerable sections and in rural areas. 
(iii) Suggest ways in which SSCs across these segments can become self-sustaining.  
11.  Gender  and  social  development  specialist  (1  national  consultant,  3  person-
months). The gender and social development specialist will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Help NSDC to collect and analyze gender-disaggregated data for the skills development 
and vocational training projects it supports. He or she will work with NSDC to strengthen 
the social and gender aspects of the memorandums of understanding it signs with 
private skills providers.   
(ii)  Work with the two pilot SSCs to ensure that social and gender concerns are adequately 
reflected  in  the  occupation  standards,  skills  requirement,  and  safety  norms.  The 
specialist will prepare a report on the basis of this work, which can help mainstream 
social and gender concerns into the work of other SSCs as appropriate.

B.  Individual Consultants    
 
12.  Advanced  technical  and  vocational  education  and  training-national  vocational 
qualifications framework policy advisor (1 international consultant, 3 person-months). 
The establishment of a vocational qualifications framework in India with the involvement of 
industry, professional bodies, and community stakeholders will provide the government with a 
uniform platform for ensuring that all the programs for vocational education and training are 
linked to one another and support the overall national development objectives. The NVQF can 
promote synergy between the higher education sector and the SSCs, and mainstream the new 
vocational qualifications developed by the SSCs. The TVET-NVQF policy advisor will dialogue 
with  relevant  entities  (including  NSDC,  the  Planning  Commission,  MOLE,  and  Ministry  of 
Human Resources and Development) to ensure that the potential for delivery of qualifications at 
the higher end of the value chain through more advanced education and training institutions is 
tapped. Specifically, the advisor will undertake the following tasks: 
 
(i)  Report on international best practice in the delivery of applied advanced education 
qualifications to meet the needs of industry and various professions. He or she will 
review the current situation in India with regard to the delivery of technology-related and 
other applied advanced qualifications. 
(ii)  Advise  on  ways  of  linking  the  skills  value  chains  identified  by  the  SSCs  with  the 
programs offered by higher academic institutions in India. Draft a medium-term strategy 
for linking selected higher education institutions to the NVQF and the SSCs, and advise 
NSDC and the Planning Commission on policies to promote the active engagement of 
higher education institutions with SSCs and their new vocational qualifications in the 
areas of assessment and certification.  
 
13.  Technical and vocational education and training-national vocational qualifications 
framework policy specialists (2 national consultants, up to 2 person-months each). A 
panel of national consultants will be made available to support the advisory work of entities such 
as  the  Planning  Commission  of  India  so  that evolving  policy  queries  in  the  areas  of  skill 
development and linkages with NVQF and higher education can be analyzed and addressed. 
This will facilitate policy dialogue and debate, draw on cross-country experience, and ensure 
that India’s skills development initiatives remain on the right track.
